metadata.title: Influence of nano-silica on the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of transparent intumescent fire-retardant coatings

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Progress in Organic Coatings
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/porgcoat
Influence of nano-silica on the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of transparent intumescent fire-retardant coatings
Long Yana,b,⁎, Zhisheng Xua,b, Xinghua Wanga
a School of Civil Engineering, Central South University, Changsha 410075, China b Institute of Disaster Prevention Science and Safety Technology, Central South University, Changsha 410075, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-silica Flame retardancy Smoke suppression Thermal stability Transparent fire-retardant coating
A B S T R A C T
A cyclic phosphate ester acid (PEA) was synthesized by the reaction of phosphoric acid (PA), pentaerythritol (PER) and n-butyl alcohol (BA). Then nano-silica was successfully introduced into the structure of PEA to obtain SPEAs with different nano-silica contents. The chemical structures of PEA and SPEAs were confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR). A series of fireretardant coatings coated on the plywood boards were prepared by mixing of melamine formaldehyde resin with PEA and SPEAs. The transparency analysis indicates that the incorporation of nano-silica into the coatings through chemical grafting method acquires high degree of transparency due to the homogeneous dispersion of each element in the coatings, judging by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The influence of nano-silica on the thermal stability, flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of coatings were investigated in details by cabinet method test, tunnel method test, cone calorimeter test, smoke density test, thermo-gravimetric analysis (TG), FTIR, SEM and EDS. The results show that the values of weight loss, char index, flame spread rating, heat release rate, total heat release, smoke production rate, total smoke release and specific optical density of the coatings are remarkably decreased with the introduction of nano-silica, which is due to the formation of a compact and intumescent char layer during combustion. The TG results demonstrate that the incorporation of nano-silica increases the thermal stability and residual weight of the coatings. The char residue analysis reveals that the nano-silica enhances the char-forming ability, intumescence and antioxidation property of the coatings due to the synergistic effect existed between phosphorus and silicon, leading to a stronger shielding effect in condensed phase. Based on these facts, the introduction of nano-silica could promote the formation of a more compact and intumescent char layer and then effectively reduces the heat and smoke release, thereby enhancing the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of coatings.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of intumescent fire-retardant coatings is one of the most effective ways to protect substrates against fire. When heated, intumescent fire-retardant coatings can swell and form a thick porous layer, which acts as a physical barrier to prevent the underlying material against the flame or heat [1]. The traditional intumescent fireretardant coatings are prepared by physically blending the intumescent flame retardants with matrix resin directly, which usually lead to the opacity of coatings [2,3]. However, some special facilities such as ancient buildings, culture relics, heritage conservations and architectural decorations need to use transparent intumescent fire-retardant coatings for maintaining their original morphology [4]. Therefore, it should be given great attention on the research and developing of transparent
intumescent fire-retardant coatings. Generally, transparent intumescent fire-retardant coatings are prepared by combining the reactive-type flame retardants with matrix resin rather than by mixing the additive-type flame retardants with matrix resin directly, which usually consist three active ingredients (acid source, carbon source, blowing agent) in the chemical structure of the coatings [4,5]. Phosphorus-containing compounds as a typical kind of reactive-type flame retardant contain both carbon source and acid source, which can react with matrix resin and then form transparent fire-retardant coatings grafting flame retardant segments [6–8]. Phosphate ester acid (PEA) with cyclic structure is considered as a promising flame retardants for preparing transparent fire-retardant coatings with high fire protection efficiency [9]. and polyethylene glycol through a two-step reaction, and then reacted with amino resin to obtain novel transparent fire-retardant coatings [4]. Shi et al. synthesized novel PEPA-containing polyether flame retardants by the reaction of 1-oxo-4-hydroxymethyl-2,6,7-trioxa-L-phosphabicyclo [2.2.2] octane (PEPA), phosphorus oxychloride (POCl3) and polyether with different structures (PEG, PPG, and PTMG), and then applied it as a reactive-type flame retardant in amino transparent intumescent fire-retardant coatings [10]. Moreover, to endow transparent fire-retardant coatings with excellent flame retardancy, some studies focused on the introduction of functional groups and flame retardant elements such as epoxy resin[11], silicon-containing epoxy compounds [9], polyethylene glycol [12,13] and organic siloxane [6] into the structure of phosphorus-containing compounds. But some functional groups such as epoxy compounds will release a large amount of smoke particles during burning, resulting in the increase of fire hazards [14]. In case of fire, the damage from smoke sometimes exceeds the fire itself [15]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop high efficiency transparent fire-retardant coatings with excellent flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties.
The incorporation of nano-sized fillers as synergist into intumescent systems shows great potential to enhance the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of intumescent coatings by enhancing the charring and reducing the formation of gaseous combustibles and soot particles [16,17]. As is known, silica nanoparticles as 0D particulate materials have attracted much attention due to their high thermal stability and heat insulation property [18]. It has been indicated that the nano-silica is a promising alternative to improve the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of intumescent systems due to the synergistic effect between silicon and phosphorus [19,20]. But the directly incorporation of nano-silica into transparent coatings by physical mean will sacrifice the optical transparency of the coatings due to the difference in a refractive index between the nano-silica and matrix resin [21,22]. Some studies indicated that the nano-silica with special treatment can use to prepare transparent silicone rubber compounds [22], transparent waterborne ultraviolet-curable polyurethane [23], transparent UV-cured coatings [24,25] and transparent fluorocarbon coatings [26]. Alongi et al. showed that the silica coatings assembled by Layer by Layer (LbL) not only maintain the original morphology of cotton fibres and polyester fabrics but also enhance the flame retardant and smoke suppression properties of the underlying substrates [27–29]. However, there are relatively few studies on the application and study of nano-silica in transparent intumescent fireretardant coatings as flame retardant.
In this study, a phosphate ester acid (PEA) with cyclic structure was synthesized by reaction of phosphoric acid (PA), pentaerythritol (PER) and n-butyl alcohol (BA). The nano-silica was introduced into the structure of PEA to obtain silica-modified cyclic polyphosphate (SPEAs). Four kinds of SPEAs with different nano-silica contents were synthesized. The chemical structures of PEA and SPEAs were confirmed by 1H NMR and FTIR. The PEA and SPEAs were mixed thoroughly with melamine formaldehyde resin to prepare a series of transparent fireretardant coatings. The flame retardant and smoke suppression properties of the coatings were intensively investigated by cabinet method test, tunnel method test, cone colorimeter test and smoke density test. The thermal degradation behaviors of the coatings were analyzed by thermo-gravimetric analysis. Finally, the char residues left after cone calorimeter test were examined by SEM, EDS and FTIR and their relationships with flame retardant and smoke suppression mechanisms were discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Phosphoric acid (PA, 85% in water) was supplied by Hunan Huihong Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Pentaerythritol (PER) was
supplied by Shanghai Qiangshun Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). N-butyl alcohol (BA) was supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Melamine formaldehyde resin (MF, model 303-80, 58–62% in n-butyl alcohol) was purchased from Jiyang Sanqiang Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). (3-Aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (KH550) was provided by Shanghai Aladdin Industrial Corporation (China). Nano-silica was supplied by Chengdu Gracia Chemical Technology Co. Ltd. (China), with the average primary particle size being 15 nm and the specific surface area being 200 ± 25 m2/g. All the reagents mentioned above were used as received.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of PEA and SPEAs
sections.text:
The mixture of PA (92.24 g, 0.8 mol), PER (29.95 g, 0.22 mol) and BA (5.93 g, 0.08 mol) were added into a 500 ml three-neck flask and magnetically stirred under refluxing for 4 h at 105 °C. A light yellow transparent liquid product was obtained and named as PEA.
KH550 modified silica was prepared according to literature method [30] with some modifications. Firstly, 20 g silica nanoparticles were dispersed in 300 ml alcohol and added into a three-neck flask under magnetic stirring. Then, 1 g KH550 was added into the silica nanoparticles dispersion and the mixture was stirred under refluxing for 4 h at 120 °C. After that the nano-silica dispersion was cooled down and separated by centrifugation. The separated silica was washed by ethanol for five times and then dried at 60 °C overnight. The obtained dry powder was amino-functionalized nano-silica (KH550-SiO2).
SPEAs were prepared by dropping the KH550-SiO2 into the above PEA system and stirred under refluxing for 4 h at 120 °C. PEA and KH550-SiO2 were reacted with mass ratio of 99:1, 98:2, 97:3 and 95:5, respectively. The SPEAs with 1 wt%, 2 wt%, 3 wt% and 5 wt% of KH550-SiO2 were marked SPEA1, SPEA2, SPEA3 and SPEA4, respectively.
2.3. Preparation of transparent fire-retardant coatings
Fifty grams of PEA or SPEAs ethanol solution (60 wt%) and 60 g MF n-butyl alcohol solution (58–62 wt%) were mixed thoroughly to get homogenous transparent coatings. The obtained coatings were coated on the plywood boards (100 mm× 100 mm× 4 mm, 75 mm× 75 mm× 4 mm and 600 mm× 90 mm× 4 mm) with the wet coating density of 500 g/m2. This process was repeated for several times until the coatings were cured to thick transparent film at room temperature. The thickness of the coatings was 0.4 ± 0.02 mm according to the average of five determinations. The plywood boards with the dimensions of 300 mm× 150 mm× 4 mm was coated with the wet coating density of 250 g/m2. This process was repeated for several times, and the thickness of dry film was 0.2 ±0.02 mm. The coatings obtained from PEA and SPEA1-SPEA4 were marked as MSPE0 and MSPE1MSPE4, respectively. In addition, PEA was directly mixed with 3 wt% KH550-SiO2 at room temperature, then fifty grams of the mixture ethanol solution (60 wt%) was mixed with 60 g MF n-butyl alcohol solution (58–62 wt%) to obtain MSPE5 coating.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurements and characterization
sections.text:
FTIR spectra were obtained from a Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (Nicolet Nexsus 670) at 1 cm−1 resolution, and the sample of char residues after cone calorimeter test was analyzed by using KBr pellet. The FTIR spectra were recorded over the range of 4000–500 cm−1. 1H NMR spectra were obtained at room temperature on a Bruker Ascend 500 MHz NMR spectrometer with D2O as the solvent.
The transparency of fire-retardant coatings was measured in a LS116-type light transmittance meter (Shenzhen Linshang Technology Co. Ltd, China). All the samples were coated on the transparent glass slide with the thickness of 0.2 ± 0.02 mm. Each glass side was with the
dimensions of 25.4 mm× 76.2 mm× 1 mm. The final values of the coatings were the average of five determinations.
The morphology analysis of char residues after cone calorimeter test was carried out on a MIRA 3 LMU scanning electron microscopy (Tescan, Czech Republic) under the voltage of 20 kV. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was carried out on the same SEM at the voltage of 20 kV using a X-Max20 X-ray probe (Oxford instruments, UK) for elemental analysis.
The cone calorimeter (FTT, UK) test was performed according to ISO5660-2002 standard procedures. Each plywood board with dimensions of 100 mm× 100 mm× 4 mm coated with a transparent coating was wrapped in aluminum foil and exposed horizontally to an external heat flux of 50 kW/m2. The final values of the coatings were the average of three determinations.
The smoke density test (JQMY-2, Jian-qiao Co, China) was used to measure the smoke production behaviors of the coatings according to ISO 5659.2-2006. Each plywood board with dimensions of 75 mm× 75 mm × 4 mm coated with a transparent coating was wrapped in aluminum foil and exposed to an incident flux of 25 kW/m2 with or without the application of an ignition flame. The final values of the coatings were the average of three determinations.
Thermo-gravimetric analysis of the coating was performed by a SOTA-851 (Mettler-Toledo, Switzerland) instrument. The samples were dried at 60 °C overnight to remove the trapped solvent before the TG test. About 10 mg sample was put in an aluminum crucible at heating rate of 20 °C/min from ambient temperature to 800 °C in the nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate of 20 ml/min).
The weight loss, char index and intumescent factor (the ratio of thickness after and before burning) were determined by cabinet method test according to China standard specification GB12441-2005 and ASTM D1360-2011. Each plywood broad with the dimensions of 300 mm × 150 mm× 4 mm was measured by a XSF-1-type fire resistant paint tester (small room mode) (Jiangning Analysis Instrument Company, China). The final values of the coatings were the average of five determinations.
The flame spread rating of the coatings was studied by tunnel method test through a SDF-2-type 2-foot flame tunnel instrument (Jiangning Analysis Instrument Company, China) according to ASTM D3806-1998 and China standard specification GB 12441-2005. Each plywood broad with dimensions of 600 mm× 90 mm × 4 mm was coated with a transparent coating. The flame spread rating (FSR) of specimen was calculated by formula (1).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of PEA and SPEAs
sections.text:
Phosphate ester acid (PEA) is achieved by the esterification reaction between PA, PER and BA. Silica nanoparticles are introduced into the structure of PEA by the reaction of amino in amino-functionalized silica nanoparticles (KH550-SiO2) and PeOH and CeOH group in PEA. The synthesis route of KH550-SiO2 is presented on Scheme 1, and the possible reaction formula of SPEAs is shown in Scheme 2.
The FTIR spectra of the unmodified SiO2 and KH550 modified SiO2 nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 1. In the spectra of SiO2 and KH550SiO2, the absorption peak at 3446 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibrations of eOH group in adsorbed water molecule, and the peaks at 1635, 1104 and 804 cm−1 are assigned to the vibrations of eOH and SieOeSi groups in the SiO2. The new absorption peaks at
2957 and 2852 cm−1 are attributed to the vibrations of eCH2 asymmetric and symmetric stretches, respectively, which confirm that chemical reaction between the SieOH groups generated by hydrolysis of the alkoxy groups of KH550 with the hydroxyl groups on the silica surface. These results indicate that the KH550 has been grafted onto the surface of silica nanoparticles as shown in Scheme 1.
The FTIR spectra of PEA and SPEAs are shown in Fig. 2. In the FTIR spectrum of PEA and SPEAs, the absorption bands at 3425 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibration of eOH groups [31]. The new absorption peaks around 3300 cm−1 are ascribed to the vibrations of eOH in SieOH groups. The absorption peaks at 2350 cm−1 stand for the vibration of PeOH group. The absorption peaks at 1465 cm−1 are attributed to deformation vibration of CeH group. The new absorption peaks at 1140 cm−1 are attributed to stretching vibration of CeNeC group [32], demonstrating that the amino groups in KH550-SiO2 have reacted with CeOH groups in PEA. The absorption peaks around 1006 and 890 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of exocyclic PeOeC group and the PeOeC group in cyclic phosphates [33]. As for SPEAs, the absorption peaks at 1006 cm−1 become stronger with the increase of nano-silica content, and the strong absorption peaks are due to the overlapping vibration modes involving mainly SieOeSi, PeOeC and PeN bands. From the new absorption bands around 3300 and 1140 cm−1 and strong absorption at 1006 cm−1, it can be inferred that the silica nanoparticles have been grafted onto the structure in PEA.
To further confirm the structures of samples, the 1H NMR spectra of PEA and SPEA3 are shown in Fig. 3. In the 1H NMR spectra of PEA, the two major chemical shifts in 4.92 ppm and 2.88 ppm are assigned to the cyclic H atoms in cyclic structure and exocyclic H atoms in exocyclic structure, respectively. The peaks at 3.21–3.47 ppm are assigned to the exocyclic H atoms in PER adjacent to cyclic structure, as shown in Fig. 3. The peaks at 0.17–0.82 ppm are attributed to the H atoms in nbutyl alcohol adjacent to phosphate. When silica nanoparticles are introduced, the chemical shifts of exocyclic H atoms are changed to 2.62–3.20 ppm in SPEA3 from 2.88–3.47 ppm in PEA, as shown in Fig. 3. The chemical shifts of exocyclic H atoms in SPEA3 are obviously different from that of PEA, confirming that the success in reaction between KH550-SiO2 and PEA. In addition, the H atoms from n-butyl alcohol are changed to−0.09 to 0.64 ppm in SPEA3 from 0.17–0.82 ppm in PEA due to the Si atoms in the structure of SPEA3. The H atoms in the structure of eCH2eCH2eCH2 from KH550 are also observed around −0.09 ppm. This result is consistent with conclusion of FTIR spectrum. According to the above results, it is confirmed by FTIR and 1H NMR spectra that PEA and SPEAs were synthesized successfully as shown in Scheme 2.
The digital images of PEA and SPEAs are displayed in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4, it can be seen that the PEA and SPEAs form a yellowish and homogeneous liquid. With the increase of silica content, the transparency of SPEAs is decreased (SPEA1 < SPEA2 < SPEA3 < SPEA4), and the SPEAs gradually turn to a yellowish-white liquid. In all the samples, no phase separation is observed by the naked eye, indicating that silica nanoparticles are dispersed uniformly in SPEAs samples by introducing into the structure of PEA.

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphology analysis
sections.text:
The morphology of the coatings were assessed by digital camera and EDS mapping. The digital images of plywood coated with different transparent fire-retardant coatings are shown in Fig. 5. The value of the transparency of each coating is shown under the images. From MSPE0 to MSPE4, the transparency of the coatings slightly decreases with the increasing content of nano-silica, which are still characterized by high degree of transparency. However, the transparency of MSPE5 is reduced to 65.58% after adding nano-silica by physical blending method, which is considerably lower than that of MSPE0. It reveals that the silica nanoparticles can be used for preparing transparent coatings by chemical grafting method instead of physical blending method. The
reason for this phenomenon is that the uniform dispersion of silica nanoparticles in the coatings, which is confirmed by the SEM-EDS analysis as shown in Fig. 6.
As shown in Fig. 6, the carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, silicon elements are uniformly distributed in the coating, and no agglomeration of nano-silica takes place. The good distribution of each element can promote the formation of a homogeneous coating, resulting in high degree of transparency for the coating.

sections.heading: 3.3. Thermal stability analysis
sections.text:
The thermo-gravimetric curves of transparent fire-retardant coatings are presented in Fig. 7, and the relevant data are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the fire-retardant coatings mainly decompose in two stages with the temperature ranges of 50–200 °C and 200–550 °C respectively. The first stage at 50–200 °C is attributed to the dehydration and volatilization of some small molecules, corresponding to little mass
loss (<10 wt%). The second stage at 200–550 °C is caused by the decomposition of amino resin and phosphate ester, corresponding to a strong DTG peak and large mass loss (>50 wt%). At this stage, the PEA and SPEAs break down to yield phosphoric acid derivatives and carbonaceous residue, which form the molten char layer. The amino resin breaks down to release non-combustible gas which expands to the molten char layer, leading to the formation of intumescent char layer. As for MSPE0, it begins to decompose at about 124.2 °C, and reaches the maximum mass loss temperature (Tmax) at about 337.2 °C with 26.1% char residue left at 800 °C. For MSPE1 to MSPE5, their onset decomposition temperatures (Td) and Tmax are higher than MSPE0, indicative of the enhancement of thermal stability by incorporation of
silica nanoparticles. In addition, the mass loss rate of coating with nanosilica is lower than that of MSPE0 during decomposition process, signifying the less release of pyrolysis products and then more char residue remained. The final residual weights of MSPE1 to MSPE5 are 29.3, 31.1, 35.2, 34.2 and 27.3%, respectively, showing an improvement in comparison with MSPE0 efficiently. The MSPE3 shows the maximum char yield and thermal stability among all coatings. These results indicate that the silica nanoparticles could effectively promote the crosslinking reaction of the degradation products in the condensed phase, which help to enhance the thermal stability and char yield of the coatings, as supported by Lv [30]. Meanwhile, it is noted that the MSPE3 exhibits the higher thermal stability and char yield compared to MSPE5 by

adding the same nano-silica content, indicative that the introduction of nano-silica by chemical grafting method has a better synergistic role in improving the char-forming ability and thermal stability of the coating than that of physical blending method.

sections.heading: 3.4. Fire protection test
sections.text:
Fire protection test including cabinet method and tunnel method tests is one of the most direct methods to assess the flame retardant properties of the fire-retarded coatings. The flame spread rating (FSR) values of the fire-retardant coatings are shown in Fig. 8. It can be seen that the application of fire-retardant coatings significantly decreases the FSR values of the samples. Moreover, the incorporation of nano-silica decreases the FSR values of the coatings, indicating that the nano-silica has good flame-retarded effect on the coatings. When the same content of nano-silica is added, the MSPE3 has the low FSR value than that of MSPE5. And, the MPSE3 acquires the lowest FSR value among above samples, exhibiting the best fire protection performance.
The weight loss, char index and intumescent factor of the transparent coatings obtained from cabinet method test are listed in Table 2. It can be seen that the transparent coatings significantly decrease the weight loss and char index of samples, and the MSPE3 acquires the lowest weight loss and char index among above samples. The intumescent factor of coating increases with the addition of nano-silica. The MSPE3 acquires the highest intumescent factor of 56.7, coinciding with the best fire protection performance obtained by cabinet method and tunnel method tests. The above results indicate that the nano-silica exhibits good synergistic effect on the fire protection properties of coatings, and the incorporation of nano-silica in the coatings by chemical bonds exhibits better synergistic effect on the fire protection performance than that of physical forces.

sections.heading: 3.5. Cone calorimeter test
sections.text:
The cone calorimeter test as a standard and universal method is widely used to evaluate the flame retardancy of fire-retarded coatings. Some cone calorimetric parameters of cone calorimeter test including peak heat release rate (PHRR), total heat release (THR), peak smoke production rate (PSPR), total smoke release (TSR) and residual weight are shown in Table 3.
The heat release rate (HRR) curves of the transparent fire-retardant coatings are shown in Fig. 9. As shown in Fig. 9, the MPSE0 burns fast and has a single peak heat release rate (PHRR) of 150.9 kW/m2 after ignition. The PHRR values of coatings are greatly decreased with the introduction of silica nanoparticles. From MSPE1 to MSPE4, the PHRR values are 133.2, 112.7, 96.2 and 104.6 kW/m2, respectively, which are lower than that of MPSE0. The PHRR values of coatings decrease firstly and then increase with the content of nano-silica increasing, and the MSPE3 shows the lowest PHRR value among above coatings, coinciding with that obtained by tunnel method and cabinet method tests. The effective decrease of PHRR indicates that the addition of silica nanoparticles could greatly enhance the flame retardancy of transparent coatings. But excessive content of nano-silica may solidify the molten char layer then inhibit the intumescence and decrease the intumescence ratio of the coatings as shown in Table 2, thus resulting in the decrease of synergistic effect on fire performance.
The total heat release (THR) curves of the coatings are presented in Fig. 10. From MSPE0 to MSPE4, the THR values are 5.4, 4.7, 3.4, 2.4 and 2.8 MJ/m2, respectively. It can be seen that the THR value is decreased with the addition of silica nanoparticles. The MSPE3 has the lowest THR among the coatings, which is 55.6% lower than that of MSPE0. It suggests that the silica nanoparticles could effectively promote the formation of char layer and provide a physical barrier to retard the heat and mass transfers between the flame and the coating, resulting in better flame retardancy. This is consistent with the results obtained by thermal gravimetric analysis. Moreover, a moderate
Td onset decomposition temperature (5 mass% mass loss), Tmax maximum mass loss temperature, PMLR1 peak mass loss rate at first stage, PMLR2 peak mass loss rate at second stage.
content of nano-silica can effectively improve the structure of char layer and make the char layer more smooth and compact. As a result, the HRR and THR values of the fire-retardant coatings are strongly decreased with the introduction of nano-silica, and the MSPE3 has the lowest PHRR and THR values than others, as shown in Figs. 9 and 10.
The dynamic smoke production behaviors of the transparent coatings are assessed by the cone calorimeter test. The smoke production
rate (SPR) and total smoke release (TSR) curves are shown in Figs. 11 and 12, respectively. As shown in Fig. 11, it can be seen that the MSPE0 rapidly reaches the peak SPR value of 0.0017 m2/s at 20 s in the combustion process. With the introduction of silica nanoparticles, the peak SPR values of coatings decrease greatly, indicating that the silica nanoparticles exhibit good smoke suppression effect in the coatings. Among all coatings, MSPE3 shows the lowest peak SPR value of 0.00065 m2/s, which is 61.8% lower than that in case of MSPE0. But it is noted that the peak SPR value of MSPE4 is increased slightly compared to MSPE3. It can be explained by the fact that a proper content of

silica nanoparticles can effectively promote charring and increase the residual amount of coatings, as confirmed by the TG results. The more char residues formed in samples could act as a better physical barrier against the release of combustible gas and smoke particulates in the burning process, resulting in the SPR reduction.
The total smoke release (TSR) curves of the coatings are shown in Fig. 12. It is clear that the TSR is significantly decreased with introduction of silica nanoparticles. From MSPE0 to MSPE4, the TSR values are 3.2, 2.4, 2.0, 1.5 and 1.7 m2/m2, respectively. The MSPE3 presents the lowest TSR value, which is decreased by 53.1% compared to that of MSPE0. It obtains the same conclusion with the results of SPR. When the coating is heated, the coating quickly volatilizes a large amount of small molecules including H2O, CH3OH, HCHO and amines, as supported by Wang [13], resulting in the rapid release of smoke precursors. But the introduction of nano-silica could improve the thermal stability of coating in this process, resulting in less release of smoke precursors. In addition, the silica nanoparticles can promote the
charring behavior and increase the residual weight of coatings at high temperature. Then, the formation of more char residue could effectively reduce the release of smoke particulates, resulting in low SPR and TSR.

sections.heading: 3.6. Smoke density test
sections.text:
To get detailed information about the smoke behavior of transparent coatings, the static smoke production behaviors are assessed by smoke density test under different combustion conditions at a flux of 25 kW/m2. The specific optical density (Ds) values of the coatings with and without flame are listed in Table 4.
The Ds curves of the coatings are presented in Fig. 13. As shown in Fig. 13a, the Ds of MSPE0 rapidly increases in the first 400 s and obtains the maximum Ds value of 14.0 at 420 s and slightly decreases after 420 s and then gets the Ds value of 12.6 at 900 s under a heat flux of 25 kW/m2 without flame in the smoke density test. When the silica nanoparticles are introduced into the coatings, the Ds curves greatly decrease in the first 400 s. The MSPE3 shows the lowest Ds value of 7.9 at 900 s, which is decreased by 37.3% compared to that of MSPE0.
The Ds curves of coatings with flame in the smoke density test are shown in Fig. 13b. It can be seen that the Ds curves of coatings show a slow increasing in the combustion process, indicating that the smoke precursors derived from the degradation will be burnt to generate smoke continuously. As shown in Fig. 13b, the Ds values of coatings with addition of nano-silica are significantly decreased compared to MSPE0, which may be ascribed to the generation rate of smoke particulates decreases with the formation of more char residue during burning. Among all coatings, the MSPE3 shows the lowest Ds value of 6.1 at 900 s, which is reduced by 43.5% compared to that of MSPE0.
Comparing Fig. 13b with Fig. 13a, it can be found that a similar decreasing trend appears in Ds curves with incorporation of silica nanoparticles in the smoke density test with and without flame. But, the Ds value of the sample in the test with flame is relatively lower than that of without flame as listed in Table 4. The reason is that the smoke precursors generated from degradation will be further decomposed into H2O, CO2 and NH3 with flame. All the results reveal that the silica nanoparticles could greatly decrease the smoke production of the coatings during combustion.

sections.heading: 3.7. Char residue analysis
sections.text:
The digital photos of char residues from the coatings after cone calorimeter test are shown in Fig. 14. The underlying structures of plywood with each coating are shown under the images of char residues. For MSPE0, the char layer shows obvious collapse structure with some big cracks at the surface, and the underlying substrate appears obvious carbonized structures. With addition of silica nanoparticles, the coatings trend to form a more continuous, compact and intumescent char layer after combustion. And, the underlying plywood shows less carbonized structure after cone calorimeter test. It indicates that the silica nanoparticles have strong condensed phase activity by charring and intumescence, which help to promote the formation of high quality of char layer. It is noted that the compactness of char layer increases with the increment content of nano-silica in coatings, as shown in Fig. 14. However, the expansion ratio of the coatings increases firstly and then decreases with the increase of nano-silica content in coatings, and the expansion ratio of the coatings from MSPE0 to MSPE4 is 38.7, 45.5, 62.5, 71.2 and 58.5, respectively. The MSPE3 shows the highest expansion ratio among all coatings, coinciding with that obtained by cabinet method test. It indicates that the excessive nano-silica could suppress the intumescent process of char layer, resulting in the decrease of synergistic effect on the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of coatings.
In order to further investigate the morphologies and compositions of the char layers from the coatings, the SEM micrographs and elemental
maps are shown in Fig. 15. A loose structure with big voids and cracks in MSPE0 is observed from Fig. 15a. As shown in Fig. 15b, almost no voids and cracks are found for the char residue of the coating containing nano-silica, indicating more compact and continuous char is formed. The elemental maps show that the coatings maintain the original elements after combustion, and the MSPE3 maintains a high content of carbon, oxygen and nitrogen elements in char layer compared to MSPE0. And, the corresponding C/O ratio of char layer for MSPE3 is higher than that of MSPE0, indicative that the antioxidation property of the char layer increases with the introduction of nano-silica, as supported by Hu [4]. It is further verified the existence of synergistic effect between phosphorus and silicon in the coatings. The above results illustrate that the silica nanoparticles can greatly contribute to the charforming process of coatings and increase the quality of char layer during combustion, thus enhancing the flame retardant and smoke
suppression properties of the transparent coatings. The chemical structure of char residue after cone calorimeter test was investigated by FTIR spectra. As shown in Fig. 16, the strong absorptions around 3375 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of eNH2 and eOH groups [13]. The new peak at 3130 cm−1 for samples containing nano-silica is assigned to the eNH stretching vibrations of O]CeNHeC cyclic groups in the char residue [32], indicating that the nano-silica can promote the formation of new complex nitrogencarbon structures. The peak at 2350 cm−1 is due to the vibration of PeOH on the structure of PEA or SPEAs. And the peak around 1626 cm−1 is ascribed to the eC]Ce structure generating from the thermal degradation of PER on the structure of PEA or SPEAs [13]. The peak at 1400 cm−1 is due to the vibrations of PeN structures [34], which becomes stronger with addition of nano-silica. The peaks around 1160 and 1100 cm−1 are due to the vibrations of phosphate or pyrophosphate group [35]. The peak at 987 cm−1 is assigned to the vibration of PeO bonds in the structure PeOeC groups [33]. With the addition of nano-silica, the peak at 987 cm−1 moves to a high frequency of 991 cm−1 and the bands around 991 cm−1 are broad and strong due to the overlapping vibration modes involving SieOeSi, SieOeP and PeOeC bonds [36], indicating that more PeO and SieO containing compounds remain in the char residues. The FTIR results show that the intensities of PeOeC and PeN bonds increase obviously and new vibration peak at 3130 cm−1 appears with introduction of nano-silica. It indicates that the nano-silica could catalyze the formation of crosslinking structure, leaving more nitrogen-carbon and PeOeC structures in the condensed phase, and thus increasing the weight of char residue. This is supported by the results of TG test. In addition, the nano-silica can promote the coatings to form a more compact and homogeneous char layer on the surface of residue (Figs. 14 and 15). Consequently, the introduction of nano-silica can lead to better flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of the coatings.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, the nano-silica was successfully introduced into the structure of PEA to obtain SPEAs with different silica contents by a twostep reaction. The chemical structures of PEA and SPEAs were confirmed by FTIR and 1H NMR. The PEA and SPEAs were mixed thoroughly with melamine formaldehyde resin to obtain a series of fireretarded coatings. The transparency analysis indicates that the addition of nano-silica by chemical grafting method can maintain the transparency of the coatings compared to physical blending method, which is ascribed to the uniform dispersion of nano-silica in the coatings judging by SEM-EDS analysis. The influence of nano-silica on the thermal stability, flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of transparent fire-retardant coatings were investigated by various methods.
The results show that the coatings with nano-silica exhibit a significant decreases in the weight loss, char index, FSR, HRR and THR during the combustion process, indicative that the enhancement of flame retardancy. In addition, the values of SPR, TSR and Ds of the coatings obviously decrease with addition of nano-silica, illustrating an improvement in smoke suppression properties. TG analysis results show that the silica nanoparticles can improve the thermal stability and charforming ability of the coatings. When the same amount of nano-silica is added, the chemical grafting method endows the coating with better char-forming ability and flame retardant property than that of physical blending method. FTIR analysis results indicate that nano-silica could promote the formation of crosslinking structure, leaving more nitrogencarbon and PeOeC structures in the condensed phase, then increasing the amount of char residue. The morphology analysis of char residue reveals that nano-silica can promote the formation of a more compact, continuous and intumescent char layer due to the synergistic effect existed between phosphorus and silicon in the SPEAs, which can greatly reduce the heat transfer and smoke release during combustion process, resulting in better flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties. But excessive nano-silica decreases the expansion ratio of the coating and then weakens the shielding effect of char residue, resulting in the slight decrease of synergistic effect. It is suggested that the content of nano-silica can significantly affect the coating charring and intumescence, and a moderate addition of nano-silica can dramatically improve the quality and structure of char layer. In summary, nano-silica shows excellent synergistic flame retardant and smoke suppression properties in the transparent fire-retardant coatings.

metadata.abstractText: A cyclic phosphate ester acid (PEA) was synthesized by the reaction of phosphoric acid (PA), pentaerythritol (PER) and n-butyl alcohol (BA). Then nano-silica was successfully introduced into the structure of PEA to obtain SPEAs with different nano-silica contents. The chemical structures of PEA and SPEAs were confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (H NMR). A series of fireretardant coatings coated on the plywood boards were prepared by mixing of melamine formaldehyde resin with PEA and SPEAs. The transparency analysis indicates that the incorporation of nano-silica into the coatings through chemical grafting method acquires high degree of transparency due to the homogeneous dispersion of each element in the coatings, judging by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The influence of nano-silica on the thermal stability, flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of coatings were investigated in details by cabinet method test, tunnel method test, cone calorimeter test, smoke density test, thermo-gravimetric analysis (TG), FTIR, SEM and EDS. The results show that the values of weight loss, char index, flame spread rating, heat release rate, total heat release, smoke production rate, total smoke release and specific optical density of the coatings are remarkably decreased with the introduction of nano-silica, which is due to the formation of a compact and intumescent char layer during combustion. The TG results demonstrate that the incorporation of nano-silica increases the thermal stability and residual weight of the coatings. The char residue analysis reveals that the nano-silica enhances the char-forming ability, intumescence and antioxidation property of the coatings due to the synergistic effect existed between phosphorus and silicon, leading to a stronger shielding effect in condensed phase. Based on these facts, the introduction of nano-silica could promote the formation of a more compact and intumescent char layer and then effectively reduces the heat and smoke release, thereby enhancing the flame retardancy and smoke suppression properties of coatings.
